prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ebonite Feed-Heat-Set

'Twas heat-set, and the ebonite feed
Did gyre and grimble in the gleam:
All mimsy were the mechalines,
And the cog-drouts outgrimed.

"Beware the Heat-Set, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Pyre-bird, and shun
The frumious Vexalatch!"

He took his Vorpal-rod in hand;
Long time the manxome forge he sought:
So rested he by the Chasm-crag,
And stood a while in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Heat-Set, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal-rod went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Heat-Set?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas heat-set, and the ebonite feed
Did gyre and grimble in the gleam:
All mimsy were the mechalines,
And the cog-drouts outgrimed.

poem:
The Grindsnark

Beware the Hollow Grind, my son!
The bite that slips, the keen undone!
Beware the Whetstone's whirring cry,
And shun the Fracture Zone nearby!

He took his Vise in hand;
Long time the Tempered Steel he planned—
So rested he by the Whetstone's drone,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Grindsnark, with eyes of flamehood,
Came whiffling through the Metalwood,
And glummered as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vise grip snapped, theBladetrue
He left it glinting, stark and raw,
And went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Grindsnark? Come,
My beamish lad! O frabjous day!
Kalloo Flay! O Hollow Grind, my son!
The bite is keen, the tune begun!”

poem:
The Scribblequill

’Twas glyphs on a scroll, and the scribes did scritch-
Scratch their quills where the inkwells gurgled deep.
All quivering were the page-edges, thin,
And the forgeflames near the scroll-vats sizzled sleep.

“Beware the Scribblequill, my son!
The claws that catch, the nib that bites!
Beware the Quillver bird, and shun
The frumious Parchment-sprites!”

He took his Gleamcraft hammer bright:
Long time the manxome scroll he sought—
So rested he by the Writing-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Scribblequill, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the parchment wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Gleamcraft hammer went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went whispscribing back.

“And hast thou slain the Scribblequill?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas glyphs on a scroll, and the scribes did scritch-
Scratch their quills where the inkwells gurgled deep.
All quivering were the page-edges, thin,
And the forgeflames near the scroll-vats sizzled sleep.

poem:
The Kilnwight's Warning

’Twas brillig in the brick-built glaze,
All mimsy were the tuyeres;
Hot fear the kiln-wight’s hazy maze,
Beware the Flame-Snake’s fires!

He took his flint-spray in his hand:
Long time the tileforge planned;
For stood he on the dune-dry sand,
By kiln-gape, slow andanned.

The Sizzleclaw, with eyes of burn,
In murk it ground and hissed;
One fume, past the float-slag’s turn,
It crackled hard and missed.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The spray-flame flicked and flared!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went triumphant, stared.

“And hast thou slain the Sizzleclaw?
Come to my arms, pyre-brave beam!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in the steam.

’Twas brillig in the brick-built glaze,
All mimsy were the tuyeres;
Hot fear the kiln-wight’s hazy maze,
Beware the Flame-Snake’s fires!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Compositor

IT WAS late AND the SLIthy FONTS
did GYRE and GIMble IN the TRAY;
all MIMsy WERE the LETter-FORMS,
and the PRESSgods THEY outgrabe.

"BeWARE the INKmonSTER, my CHILD!
the PRESses THAT clank with DREADful JAMS!
beWARE the FONTfiend, and FLEE far
the WHAMulous COMposING CLAMS!"

HE took his LEADrod IN his HAND,
long TIME the MONsterMAN he SOUGHT—
so PAUSED he BY the PRINTwood SHED,
and WONderSKETCHED his great THOUGHT.

AND as in WONderSKETCH he STOOD,
the INKmonSTER, WITH EYES so BLACK,
came TICKtackING THROUGH the INKling WOOD,
and MURbled AS it TRACKED back!

CLICK, clap! CLICK, clap! AND SET in LINE!
the LEADrod then went WHIRsnapSNAP!
he LEFT it SET, and PERfect YET,
he WENT GAlumphing on BACK.

"AND have YOU SET the PAGE perFECT?
come TO my ARMS, my PRINTer BOY!
o COPY day! HUZzah! HOOray!"
he CHORTled IN his bound JOY.

IT WAS late AND the SLIthy FONTS
did GYRE and GIMble IN the TRAY;
all MIMsy WERE the LETter-FORMS,
and the PRESSgods THEY outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Lacquersnatch

’Twas brillig, and the slithy brands
Did glimer in the wabe;
All mimsy were the whorled-grain wands,
And whiffled from the glade.

“Beware the Lacquersnatch, my son!
The fangs that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Glimmerbird, and shun
The frumious Urushimawock!”

He took his Varnish-sword in hand:
Long time the manxome bark he sought—
So rested he by the Tocus-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Lacquersnatch, with eyes of flame,
Came whirlwinding through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

Snap-hiss! Crack-thrum! The blade went snicker-snack!
He left it cured, and with its back
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Lacquersnatch?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillig, and the slithy brands
Did glimer in the wabe;
All mimsy were the whorled-grain wands,
And whiffled from the glade.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plumbrum's Bluing Bath

Beware the Plumbrum's bluing bite,
The Bath's brown murk, the whiffling night!
Beware the Plumgrott, and shun
The frumious Plum-spright!

He took his Vorpal Bathing-stick,
And long beside the plum-brown stream
He sought the Plumbrum, fierce and quick,
With gurgling, gibbering dream.

And as in plum-brown thought he stood,
The Plumbrum, with eyes of glowing blue,
Came whiffling through the bluing wood,
And Burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal Bathing-stick went Snicker-Snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Plumbrum?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Plumbrum's bluing bite,
The Bath's brown murk, the whiffling night!
Beware the Plumgrott, and shun
The frumious Plum-spright!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Platformums

’Twas platform-time, and travel-shy
Did hest and shudder in the sky;
All wary-eyed the watchers stood,
Beware the Trundlekin, they cried!

He packed his grip with skelpt and haste,
The frumious Whumpel-beast faced;
One moment lost, the platforms twist,
Beware the Trundlekin! Take thy flight!

Long time the站台-watchman stood,
His gaze fixed on the brooding wood
Where tremors woke the iron track,
The Whumpel-beast gave warning: Whump!

And as in tremulous dread he stood,
The Trundlekin, with clatter loud,
Came whiffling through the gathered crowd,
And burst its bellows in a cloud!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The whump-whump air did swiftly blew!
He left the beast, and with a click,
He boarded swift, the engines thick!

“And hast thou fled the Trundlekin?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in departing joy.

’Twas platform-quiet, travel-gone,
The等待-roomed stood still, pale and wan;
All sighed relief, the watchers stood,
Beware the Trundlekin! Take thy flight!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Inkbryo

’Twas brillig, and the slythe inks
Did mire and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the momeraths outgrabe.

“Beware the Inkbryo, my son!
The stains that smear, the claws that catch!
Beware the Scrawl-bird, and shun
The frumious Drench-snatch!”

He took his vorpal brayer in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Inkbryo, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Inkbryo?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillig, and the slythe inks
Did mire and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the momeraths outgrabe.

poem:
**Summit Prayer Flag**

Beware the Glimmergripe, my son!
The claws that snatch, the fangs that bite!
Beware the Whispermist, and shun
The frumious Zephyr-wight!

He took his Vexstaff in hand;
Long time the manxome flag he sought:
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Glimmergripe, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vexstaff went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Glimmergripe?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Postsetter's Quest

Beware the F-holes, luthier dear!
The brumles, that with hollowhowl creep;
Beware the gilded glimfray clear,
And shun the frumious soundboard deep.

He took his postsetter in hand:
Long time the maplerium sought;
So rested he by the tonewood tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in glumgy thought he stood,
The F-holes, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

Clonk! Clatter! through the spruce it went!
He set it left, he set it right!
He chuffed it with a grumble cent,
And made the aria bright.

And hast thou tuned the tonewood forte?
Come to my arms, my practiced lad!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his glad.

Beware the F-holes, luthier dear!
The brumles, that with hollowhowl creep;
Beware the gilded glimfray clear,
And shun the frumious soundboard deep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cereus Vigil

'Twas cereus-midnight, mumsy and deep,
Where shadow-things their secrets keep.
All whisht the garden, still and stark,
Lest Cereus-Waker mark the dark.

Beware the Glimmerwing, so fleet!
Beware the Nox-bat, soft and sweet!
Beware the Pallid-Prowler's spin,
That steals the moonlight, thin from thin!

He took his Starglass, bright and keen;
He sought the Hill of Moonlit Green.
Long watched he by the stone-wrought wall,
Whispering low a lulling thrall.

And, as in wistful dreamings deep,
The Cereus woke from ancient sleep.
One silver whorl did unfurl, a sigh,
Against the indigo-knit sky.

Then Glimmerwing, a flicker bright,
Did sipsip-feed on witching-light!
One, two! Through cereus-scented air,
He darted, quick beyond compare!

"Nox-bat! Pallid-Prowler, flee!"
He raised his sceptre bravely.
Sternumous swung his arm so fleet,
And Gallumphed the threat so fleet!

He left it murzzled, mute and grim,
By stone-wrought wall, serenely dim.
And hastened back ere dawn was nigh,
Where cereus-midnight dreams still lie.

'Twas cereus-midnight, mumsy and deep,
Where shadow-things their secrets keep.
The bloom now bowed, its vigil spent,
And slumbered, silver-scented, sent.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
O Synthlewick

'Twas vidibrume, and the sly therbs
Did gyre and gimble in the rack;
All fuzzy were the oscillator verbs,
And the patchpoints mimsy out the back.

“Beware the Synthlewick, my son!
The jaws that chomp, the cables covet!
Beware the Glitch-bird, and shun
The frumious Knot-devour’s it!”

He took his patch-snake tool in hand;
Long time the feedback loop he sought—
So rested he by the VCA stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Synthlewick, with eyes of LED,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The patch-snake tool went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Synthlewick?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas vidibrume, and the sly therbs
Did gyre and gimble in the rack;
All fuzzy were the oscillator verbs,
And the patchpoints mimsy out the back.

poem:
The Wow-Flutterbeast

’Twas flickering frizz, and the Wowflits did spin
In Fluttergloam o’er spools of brown.
All mimsy were the Sprockly thin,
And the Tapeslithes writhed around.

“Beware the Wow-Flutterbeast, my son!
The warps that whirr, the drifts that hiss!
Beware the Glimmer-gnomes, and shun
The frumious Fidget-whisp!”

He took his Rec-ord blade in hand:
Long time the magnet-trace he sought—
So rested he by the Sprockly stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Wow-Flutterbeast, with eyes of sheen,
Came whiffling through the Flimmerwood,
And hiss-sputtered as it gleaned!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Rec-ord blade went snicker-snack!
He left it hissing, and with its crew,
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Wow-Flutterbeast?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas flickering frizz, and the Wowflits did spin
In Fluttergloam o’er spools of brown.
All mimsy were the Sprockly thin,
And the Tapeslithes writhed around.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Shimmerwing Shimmer**

'Twas brillig, and the opal gleams  
Did glimfleek in the glade;  
All scintillux were the prisms,  
And plink-fires gently played.

"Beware the Shimmerwing, my son!  
The chroma-flare that shifts!  
Beware the Glimworm, hue-expunge,  
And shun the fract rifts!"

He took his Chroma-Blade in hand:  
Long time the prism foe  
He sought—So rested he by the Iris-mound,  
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Shimmerwing, with eyes  
That flimmered, scorching rainbow-bright,  
Through plink-fire veils it flies!

Prism-blaze, flash-flare! It blazed through air!  
He left it scorched, bereft!  
Chroma-Blade bit, true and fair!  
He went, snick-snick, and reft!

"And hast thou slain the Shimmerwing?  
Come to my arms, my prismatic boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the opal gleams  
Did glimfleek in the glade;  
All scintillux were the prisms,  
And plink-fires gently played.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Peonyant's Morn

'Twas brillig-dim, and peony mists did curl
Around the stem-labyrinths where flitters creep.
Beware the Piffledawn, my son! The pearl
Of dew that holds the secrets ants would keep.

He took his petal-shield in hand;
Long time the manxome root he sought.
Then rested in the moss-soft land,
And whiled a moment, heedless, caught.

And, as in zuzzled sleep he lay,
The Peonyant, with eyes of flake,
Came whiffling through the dawn-fresh hay,
And glunched the stem with fragile shake.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The petal-shield went snicker-snack!
He left it glimmed, and with its crew,
He galumphed back, triumphant, back.

'Twas brillig-dim, and peony mists did curl
Around the stem-labyrinths where flitters creep.
He held the Piffledawn, my son! The pearl
Of dew that holds the secrets ants would keep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Oscilloglade's Bloom**

Beware the Oscilloglade's Bloom,
That zizzles in the gloaming gloom!
Its lissajous petals twist and swoon,
Beware the Bloom that whirs and looms!

The Wavewright took his phase-swept blade,
The cathode-ray, a light he made.
He stood a while in thought and shade,
Then galumphed through the electron glade.

And as in phosphen light he stood,
The Lissajade, with wattled wraith,
Came whiffling through the circuit wood,
And burbled as it traced its path!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The phase-swept blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Lissajade?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Oscilloglade's Bloom,
That zizzles in the gloaming gloom!
Its lissajous petals twist and swoon,
Beware the Bloom that whirs and looms!

poem:
The Civetwocky

’Twas civet-dusk, and muskralisks
Did whiffle in the wabe:
All mimsy were the ambergris,
The drydown daze did drabe.

“Beware the Muskralisk, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Patchouli-bird, and shun
The frumious Oud-wolf’s scratch!”

He took his Vial in hand:
Long time the manxome scent he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Muskralisk, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vial went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Muskralisk?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas civet-dusk, and muskralisks
Did whiffle in the wabe:
All mimsy were the ambergris,
The drydown daze did drabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Reglet and the Furniture**

'Twas brillig, and the slithy woves  
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;  
All mimsy were the borogoves,  
And the mome raths outgrabe.  

"Beware the Jubjub bird, my son!  
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!  
Beware the Fierce Furniture, and shun  
The frumious Sofactyl's snatch!"  

He took his vorpal sithe in hand:  
Long time the manxome wobbleware  
He sought—so rested he by the Tumtum tree,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Fierce Furniture, with eyes of flame,  
Came wiffling through the tulgey wood,  
And burbled as it came!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal sithe went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  

"And hast thou slain the Fierce Furniture?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.  

'Twas brillig, and the slithy woves  
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;  
All mimsy were the borogoves,  
And the mome raths outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Old Piton Scar

'Twas flindering, and the slithy schist
Did gribble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the cliff-knobs hung,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

"Beware the Scar-Fist, my son!
The claws that catch, the crags that crunch!
Beware the Rumbl-rock, and shun
The frumious Grumble-drudge!"

He took his vorpal chock in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Scar-Fist, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal chock went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Scar-Fist?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas flindering, and the slithy schist
Did gribble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the cliff-knobs hung,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shuttlewock

Twas hither-pick and loom-sprites gleam,
In warp-y wood the shuttle sped,
All friframe was the tangled beam,
And pickclack beasts at treadwheels fed.

"Beware the Shuttlewock, my son!
The jaws that pick, the claws that catch!
Beware the Pick-Bird, and shun
The Frumious Thread-Snatch!"

He took his Hook-sword in hand;
Long time the Bobbin-foam he sought,
So rested he by the Tum-tum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Shuttlewock, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the warp-tule wood,
And clattered as it came!

Whirr-clack, whirr-clack! Through warp weft!
His Hook-sword went slish-slash! He left it dead,
And with its thread, he went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Shuttlewock?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

Twas hither-pick and loom-sprites gleam,
In warp-y wood the shuttle sped,
All friframe was the tangled beam,
And pickclack beasts at treadwheels fed.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Tinsmith's Stake Song

'Twas brillig in the forges deep,
Where soldered seams did softly weep;
The anvils rang, the hammers clank,
All sleek with polish rank and dank.

"Beware the Stakelorn, my son!
The jaws that bite, the metal spun!
Beware the Stakelum bird, and shun
The frumious Hammer-ton!"

He took his tinsnip bright and keen,
He found a stake of tempered sheen;
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
Then rested on a forlorn, wrought thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Stakelorn, through the copper-wood,
Came whiffling through the tangle-grove,
And burbled as it clangorant shove!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The stake went snicker-snack! He left it dead,
And with its head went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Stakelorn?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig in the forges deep,
Where soldered seams did softly weep;
The anvils rang, the hammers clank,
All sleek with polish rank and dank.

poem:
The Petradurian

'Twas brillig, and the slithy lodes
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the marmorous todes,
And the mabeledes outgrabe.

"Beware the Petradurian, my son!
The jaws that bite, the gems that catch!
Beware the Quartz-bird, and shun
The frumious Flint-satch!"

He took his vorpal hammer in hand;
Long time the manomorphic foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

The Petradurian, with eyes of flame,

The vorpal hammer went snicker-snack!
He left it glazed, and with its brood
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Petradurian?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy lodes
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the marmorous todes,
And the mabeledes outgrabe.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Bluemoor Snark

Beware the Bluemoor's glimer-glow
That slicks the silent, swallowing snow,
When bore-bright boughs in shadow show
And biting zephyrs bitterly blow.

He took his whiffle-sword in hand:
Long time the slithy slush he scanned,
Beneath the trees where shadows stand,
In lands where no warm footprints land.

And, as in tundrish thought he stood,
The Bluemoor Snark, with eyes of wood,
Came whiffling through the chillish wood,
And gurgled as it softest shood!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The whiffle-blade went snicker-snack!
He left it slain, and traced him back,
Using its own frostfire track.

And hast thou slain the Bluemoor Snark?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his frost-worn joy.

Beware the Bluemoor's glimer-glow
That slicks the silent, swallowing snow,
When bore-bright boughs in shadow show
And biting zephyrs bitterly blow.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crosstie Creosote

'Twas creosotling, and the crosstie grooves
Did gleam and grickle in the glose:
All rails were rimbled, and the stoves
Outgrumbled in their repose.

"Beware the Crosstie-Beast, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Rustbird, and shun
The frumious Screech-Wretch!"

He took his vorpal switch-blade in hand:
Long time the manometook he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Crosstie-Beast, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Crosstie-Beast?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas creosotling, and the crosstie grooves
Did gleam and grickle in the glose.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Colletwomp Gambit

Beware the Colletwomp, my son!
The coils that grip, the springs that thrum!
Beware the Tinkertock bird, and shun
The frumious Griddlegrag's glum!

He took his Sproingled wrench in hand;
Long time the mandrel groove he sought.
So rested he by the Tumbly tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Colletwomp, with eyes of brass,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One click! And through and through
The Sproingled wrench went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Colletwomp?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Colletwomp, my child!
The coils that grip, the springs that thrum!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Arc-Fiend's Galliard

Twas brillig, and the rotor-vanes
Did whirr and click on iron plains;
The metro-wires, brimstone-blue,
Cast shimmering shunts all askew.

"Beware the Arc-Feind, wiring lad!
The jaws that snap, the sparks that scad!
Beware the Volt-Wisp, and shun
The frumious Glimmer-Ground!"

He took his Zilch-rod in hand:
Long time the conductrix-planned;
Then rested he by the Tumtrack tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Arc-Feind, with eyes of scintillash,
Came whiffling through the cogwood grove,
And zuzzled as it came!

Zuzz, zuzz! Through the copse it zuzz!
One, two! One, two! The Zilch-rod blazed blue!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Arc-Feind?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

Twas brillig, and the rotor-vanes
Did whirr and click on iron plains;
The metro-wires, brimstone-blue,
Cast shimmering shunts all askew.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Starlingwocky

'Twas stubblehaze, and flicker-thin
The starlins darted, dusk-abet,
All gorgegrain in the stubble-hollow
Where shadow-grains are met.

"Beware the Flickerwing, my son!
The claws that catch, the beaks that bite!
Beware the Rabbleflight, and shun
The frumious Murmur-light!"

He took his whirr-whortle sword in hand;
Long time the stubble-fleck he sought—
So rested he by the Tumbly-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Flickerwing, with eyes of splotch,
Came whiffling through the trencher-wode,
And sizzled as it watched.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The whirr-whortle blade went snicker-snack!
He left it stabbed, and with its blood
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Flickerwing?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas stubblehaze, and flicker-thin
The starlins darted, dusk-abet,
All gorgegrain in the stubble-hollow
Where shadow-grains are met.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Pewterwyrm

'Twas brillig, and the slithy troves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

"Beware the Pewterwyrm, my son!
The filigree that snarls, the frost
Beware the Glint-worm, and shun
The frumious Inlay-wroth!"

He took his vorpal chisel in hand;
Long time the manxome forge he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Pewterwyrm, with eyes of coal,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal chisel went snicker-snack!
It traced its bright, hard line, and with a chime,
It struck a final track.

"And hast thou slain the Pewterwyrm?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy troves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brayerclatter Beast

Beware the Brayerclatter, son!
The shnackle that slip-slithers near!
It shnuffles thick with chatter done,
And grinds its ink-well slick, my dear!

He took his brayer in hand:
Long time the chitter-chatter grew,
He rested by the lino-land,
And stood awhile in thought anew.

And, as in uffish thought he sponged,
The Brayerclatter, with eyes of hue,
Came whiff-puffing through the ink-footed gloom,
And burbled as it chewed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The brayer went snip-snap! He left it dead,
And with its chattered head,
He went slip-slithering back.

And hast thou slain the Brayerclatter? Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shimmerquoth

’Twas brillig, and the slithe plumes
Did gyre and gimble in the grove;
All mimsy were the gromish dumes,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

“Beware the Shimmerquoth, my son!
The jaws that mizzle, the claws that snatch!
Beware the Glumph-bird, and shun
The frumious Vritch-patch!”

He took his vorpal flitch in hand;
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Shimmerquoth, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal flitch went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Shimmerquoth?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillig, and the slithe plumes
Did gyre and gimble in the grove;
All mimsy were the gromish dumes,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Gyring Spanner

'Twas brillig, and the slithy gears
Did gyre and gimble in the brass;
All mimsy were the cog-bound hears,
The cogs they whirred and clankéd pass.

"Beware the Gyring Spanner, son!
The jaws that snap, the clutch that grinds!
Beware the Rust-Worm, and shun
The frumious Gear-bind's reflex finds!"

He took his vorpal Wrench in hand:
Long time the manxome spring he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he sprocked,
The Gyring Spanner, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey block,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal Wrench went snicker-snack!
He left it greased, and with its crew,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Gyring Spanner?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy gears
Did gyre and gimble in the brass;
All mimsy were the cog-bound hears,
The cogs they whirred and clankéd pass.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Parrelbead

’Twas riggling, and the slick-rigged spars
Did gyre and gamble in the breeze;
All flimsy were the sail-yard bars,
And the foam waves farmed the frothful seas.

“Beware the Parrelbead, my son!
The jaws that bite, the shell that snatches!
Beware the Gaff-fowl, and shun
The frumious Sprock-snatcher!”

He took his vorpal marlinspike in hand;
Long time the manxsome tack he sought—
So rested he by the Tumble-tarn,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Parrelbead, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the riggled wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal spike went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Parrelbead?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas riggling, and the slick-rigged spars
Did gyre and gamble in the breeze;
All flimsy were the sail-yard bars,
And the foam waves farmed the frothful seas.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Ode to the Levainling**

Beware the Doughbeast, my son!  
The claws that fold, the crust that bites!  
Beware the Dormant-Scum, and shun  
The frisky Flourwhisp'sights!  

He took his Whisk-Wand in hand:  
Long time the manly crust he sought—  
So rested he by the Tepid-Tan  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Doughbeast, with eyes of gleam,  
Came burbling through the Autolyse wood,  
And bubbled as he came!  

Whisk-whisk! Whisk-whisk! And through and through  
The Whisk-Wand went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  

“And hast thou slain the Doughbeast?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O loam-warm day! Calooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

Beware the Doughbeast, my son!  
The claws that fold, the crust that bites!  
Beware the Dormant-Scum, and shun  
The frisky Flourwhisp'sights!  
*Feed the fledgling Levainling,*  
*And tend the starter's best delights.*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Borogove

’Twas flimsy, and the sitchy threads
Did gyre and gimble in the drape;
All mimsy were the thready beds,
And the motes outgrape.

“Beware the Sashikwok, my son!
The jaws that mend, the claws that catch!
Beware the Borofowl, and shun
The frumious Patchwritch!”

He took his Vorpal needle in hand:
Long time the manxome cloth he sought—
So rested he by the Tumbletree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Sashikwok, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal needle went snicker-snack!
He left it stitched, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou stitched the Sashikwok?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas flimsy, and the sitchy threads
Did gyre and gimble in the drape;
All mimsy were the thready beds,
And the motes outgrape.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glowwaker

The nixie-tube warm glimmered, slow,
Beneath the filamentum;
The Hizz-flea hopped in phosphor-glow,
And Whirr-pods sizzled, dum-de-dum.

"Beware the Humdrum, son! His deeps
Swallow the light-um all!
He shroudeth in the electric sleep,
Where gloaming-crescents fall!"

He took his Snap-wrench, long and keen;
He sought the Flicker-field;
And stood awhile in fluorescent sheen,
And warily wired, yield!ield!

And as in phased-plastic gleam he paced,
The Humdrum, eyes of ember-sheen,
Came slithering through the cooling waste,
A fritterfire unseen!

Snap-wrench! Snipp-snap! The tool went whizz!
He left it crisp, a glowing core!
One gash! One crisp! His volt-path fizz!
The Humdrum—vexed no more!

"And hast thou slain the Humdrum? Come!
My warm-bright boy! O frabjous day!
Kalloo Flay! Oh raptures some!"
He chortled in his ray.

The nixie-tube warm glimmered, slow,
Beneath the filamentum;
The Hizz-flea hopped in phosphor-glow,
And Whirr-pods sizzled, dum-de-dum.

poem:
The Snarktopod's Gouge

'Twas brillig, and the scythe-tide groaned
Past reefs of chalk and barnacled stone.
All slithery were the rock-lichened zones,
The coralline glades did writhe and moan.

"Beware the Snarktopod, my son!
The jaws that siphon, the claws that scoop!
Beware the Scalder-shark, and shun
The frumious Gouger's fishtail loop!"

He took his Vorpal Scythe in hand;
Long time the spongiform foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Snarktopod, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal Scythe went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Snarktopod?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the scythe-tide groaned
Past reefs of chalk and barnacled stone.

poem:
The Scriverella

'Twas brillig, and the slithy roves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

"Beware the Scriverella, my son!
The claws that scratch, the ink that stains!
Beware the Glumous-bird, and shun
The frumious Sable-snake!"

He took his vorpal pen in hand:
Long time the manxome form he sought —
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Scriverella, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal pen went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Scriverella?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy roves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

poem:
The Clickerclack

Beware the Staticritch, my son!
The jaws that blur, the waves that drone!
Beware the Snappledrone, and shun
The frumious Ditherdown!

He took his Vibroblade in hand;
Long time the manxome static he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum wire,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Staticritch, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the ether Lode,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vibroblade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Staticritch?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Staticritch, my son!
The jaws that blur, the waves that drone!
Beware the Snappledrone, and shun
The frumious Ditherdown!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Roslin's Fustle**

Beware the Roslin's Fustle, child,
Where fiddle rosin dust is wild!
The bowscree whines, the strings grow taut—
Beware the dread that dust has wrought!

He took his bow in hand, and clear
He polished dust with grim good cheer;
Near music stand, by tuning post,
He sought the Fustle's dreaded host.

And as he paused in soundless grace,
The dustling rose from its dark space,
With whizzled wings and fizzled eyes,
It sparked through rosin-clouded skies!

Bow to string! With fireflash bright,
He slashed the air with fierce delight!
One glinking stroke, then sharp and fast—
The dustling shot at him! He passed!

He struck it down with singing crash,
Its fizzy form dissolved in flash!
He galumphed back with joyous sound,
To where the silent dust lay 'round.

"And hast thou slain the Roslin, lad?
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He whistled soft, with joyous gleam,
And resumed his fiddle rosin dream.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Planerwock

'Twas flex-grind, and the slicky chisels  
Did whir and whorl in the wabe;  
All mimsy were the planer tizzles,  
And the shavings gimbled outgrabe.

"Beware the Planerwock, my son!  
The jaws that crunch, the claws that catch!  
Beware the Cam-bandit, and shun  
The frumious Ironous-wretch!"

He took his vorpal block in hand;  
Long time the maxiform he sought—  
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,  
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Planerwock, with eyes of flame,  
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,  
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal block went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Planerwock?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas flex-grind, and the slicky chisels  
Did whir and whorl in the wabe;  
All mimsy were the planer tizzles,  
And the shavings gimbled outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Orinbell Hum

Beware the Bell's deep hum, my son!
The jaws that toll, the claws that chime!
Beware the Orinbell, and shun
The frumious Humgrumble's time!

He took his Tolltome in hand;
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Orinbell, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Tolltome went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Orinbell?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

Through tulgey wood and Tumtum shade,
He bore the head, a clangous prize.
The Bell's deep hum began to fade
Beneath the bright, calm skies.

The Bell's deep hum began to fade,
Beneath the bright, calm skies.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Brinequench**

'Twas glimmer-gloop, and the slithy sedge  
Did crisp and crawl in the saltmarsh bed;  
All brimmy were the brine-tideedges,  
And the grombles probed with brineleech-head.  

"Beware the Brinequench, my son!  
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!  
Beware the Sizzle-slink, and shun  
The frumious Salamander-snatch!"  

He took his Scale-sieve in hand;  
Long time the wetland peace he sought—  
So rested he by the Tangle-tide,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
The Brinequench, with eyes of green-glass,  
Came whispering through the brash-salt wood,And hissed as it came with a seethe unequalled!  

Tide-tongs! Sieve-spake! He went slish-slash  
Through the spindrift spray with a flashing grin!  
He left it sapped, one steaming mass—  
Its hot cold hiss fizzled thin.  

"And hast thou slain the Brinequench?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.  

'Twas glimmer-gloop, and the slithy sedge  
Did crisp and crawl in the saltmarsh bed;  
All brimmy were the brine-tideedges,  
And the hush-hiss softly spread.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Badgerknot Bloom

'Twas grummled, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and grumble in the grove;
All grizzly were the borogoves,
And the knipscrouts outgrabe.

"Beware the Bandersnatch, my son!
The claws that catch, the jaws that bite!
Beware the Grundlebird, and shun
The frumious Badgerknot's might!"

He took his Vorpal Blade in hand:
Long time the knotted foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Badgerknot, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgy wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal Blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Badgerknot?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas grummled, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and grumble in the grove;
All grizzly were the borogoves,
And the knipscrouts outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**Nibtine Micro-Mesh**

Beware the Nibtine's micro-mesh,
Its fronds that quill and fib!  
The Mimsy-Vetch will scratch and fresh,  
When Gimbles start to bib.

He took his Vorpal Scritch-knife bright,  
Long time the grumious gem he sought;  
Then rested, breathing darkling light,  
Beside the Tumtum grove heught.

And as in slithy thought he stood,  
The Nibtine, with eyes of verdigris,  
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,  
And burbled as it hissed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The Vorpal blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Nibtine?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Nibtine's micro-mesh,  
Its fronds that quill and fib!  
The Mimsy-Vetch will scratch and fresh,  
When Gimbles start to bib.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Throatsnatcher's Tum

Beware the Throatsnatcher's tum, my son!
The jaws that bite, the boards that crumb!
Beware the Grumph-wood, and shun
The frumious Snicker-schnide!

He took his Krenovian blade in hand;
Long time the chisel-grain he sought:
So rested he by the Tumble-track,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Throatsnatcher, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Krenovian blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Throatsnatcher?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Throatsnatcher's tum, my son!
The jaws that bite, the boards that crumb!
Beware the Grumph-wood, and shun
The frumious Snicker-schnide!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Tintinnabu

'Twas plishy, and the slumbrous sprogs
Did drip and drabble in the deep;
All wimbly were the wattle-frogs,
And the tin-torrent twisted steep.

"Beware the Tintinnabu, my son!
The jaws that splatter, claws that catch!
Beware the Plum-bird, and shun
The frumious Slabble-snatch!"

He took his Vorpal-pot in hand:
Long time the manxome roof he sought—
So rested he by the Tum-tum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Tintinnabu, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Vorpal-pot went snicker-snack!
He left it clattered, and with its back,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Tintinnabu?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas plishy, and the slumbrous sprogs
Did drip and drabble in the deep;
All wimbly were the wattle-frogs,
And the tin-torrent twisted steep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Kyudrip**

Beware the Senchagyre, my son!
The jade-leaf swirl that froths and drips,
The drip that slips, the steam that grips—
Beware the Gyre-tea's spun!

He took his Kyudrop in hand;
Long time the warmful clay he sought,
So rose he from his slothful spot,
And stood awhile in dream.

And as in humid gleam he stood,
The Senchagyre, with leafy flame,
Came whiffling through the shaded glade,
And steamed as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Kyudrop dripped with steely gleam!
He left it warm, a jade-coiled stream—
He traced the spout’s bright seam!

And hast thou slain the Senchagyre?
Come to my arms, my beam-warmed boy!
O gleamagreen! O kyu-sip joy!
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Senchagyre, my son!
The jade-leaf swirl that froths and drips,
The drip that slips, the steam that grips—
Beware the Gyre-tea's spun!

poem:
The Split-Grade Toiler

"Beware the Flashgob, Son, that snaps!
Beware the Shadesnarl, stark and thin!
Beware the Flashgob's lens attack,
And shun the frumious Tweakspin!"

He took his Grade-Switch, swift and keen:
Long time the f-stop zone he sought;
Then rested by the Tint-tank green,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Flashgob, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the cellulose wood,
And burbled as it came!

Snap, flash! It gobbled silver gleam,
The paper hissed with potent burn!
One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Grade-Switch went snicker-snack!
He snatched it, snipped it, made it clean,
And with a deft turn, did adjourn.

"And hast thou slain the Flashgob? Come!
Burn-bright joy! O beam-shot day!"
He chortled in his glee-some home.

"Twas brillig, and the slithy dodols
Did gyre and gimble in the chrome;
All mimsy were the borogroves,
And the mome raths outgrabe."

poem:
**The Kiridashi's Line**

Beware the Griffle-snide, my son!
The jaws that scribble, the claws that scribe!
Beware the Scribble-sprite, and shun
The frumious Grindle-grub!

He took his keen kiridashi in hand;
Long time the whirring line he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Griffle-snide, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The kiridashi blade went snicker-snack!
He left it griddled, and with its back,
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Griffle-snide?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Griffle-snide, my son!
The jaws that scribble, the claws that scribe!
Beware the Scribble-sprite, and shun
The frumious Grindle-grub!
